title: Kindred's Long Lore has Arrived!

embed.description: Separate, but never parted, Kindred represents the twin essences of death. Lamb's bow offers a swift release from the mortal realm for those who accept their fate. Wolf hunts down those who run from their end, delivering violent finality within his crushing jaws.

body: Lists them as friends with themselves, rivals to all the undead monsters of the Shadow Isles EXCEPT Kalista, and a nice read to boot. Give it a gander!

Fiddlesticks once was a scarecrow, in fact, he still is. He scares things, and summons crows.

Out of his lore, with retcon applied-

**For nearly twenty years, Fiddlesticks has stood alone** ~~in the easternmost summoning chamber of the Institute of War.~~ **Only the burning emerald light of his unearthly gaze pierces the musty darkness of his dust-covered home. It is here that the Harbinger of Doom keeps a silent vigil.** ~~His is a cautionary tale of power run amok, taught to all summoners within the League.~~ **Decades ago, there existed a powerful rune mage from Zaun - Istvaan. At the end of the fifth Rune War,** ~~he became one of the League's first summoners. Too much a prisoner to the old ways of magic, Istvaan stepped further and further outside the rules of conduct in the League. In what was ultimately his last match, his reach finally exceeded his grasp. Sealing himself inside the easternmost summoning chamber, he began incanting the most forbidden of rituals - an extra-planar summoning.~~

~~What exactly happened inside that chamber remains unknown. No champion came to represent Zaun that day in Summoner's Rift. Only silence echoed back from repeated knocks on the chamber door. The first apprentice who entered was cut down immediately by an unearthly scythe.~~ **What few who followed and survived were driven mad by fear, mere husks of men gibbering about crows and death.** ~~Afraid of the evil even Istvaan could not control, the League sealed all exits to the chamber, hoping they could contain what they could not destroy. Years went by, but the wooden figure within never moved save to slay any foolish enough to enter. Seeing no recourse to reclaim the chamber, the Council instead devised a use for Fiddlesticks: executioner. While he comes to life and seemingly abides by the rules of summoning in the Fields of Justice, what he awaits inside his chamber is unknown.~~ **His unmoving face yields no clues, and his scythe stands ready to strike down any who stand before him.**

"Those who say 'you have nothing to fear but fear itself' have not yet felt the crows." 
---
Easier to read version-

For nearly twenty years, Fiddlesticks has stood alone.
Only the burning emerald light of his unearthly gaze pierces the musty darkness of his dust-covered home. It is here that the Harbinger of Doom keeps a silent vigil.
Decades ago, there existed a powerful rune mage from Zaun - Istvaan. At the end of the fifth Rune War,
What few who followed and survived were driven mad by fear, mere husks of men gibbering about crows and death.
His unmoving face yields no clues, and his scythe stands ready to strike down any who stand before him.
---
That's all that remains. A jumble of stuff that doesn't even make sense. Actually not even sure if Istvaan is still canon, because he was a summoner. Though, pretty sure the Rune War is still canon, so he might be.
But summed up, it's a scarecrow that hasn't moved in 20 years but people are still scared shitless of it.

To those wondering if she does the "killing blow" of sorts. Yes and no.  Kindred, in essence, is death. The best possible example I can give is the shitty movie "final destination" the actual antagonist of the movie is death.  Death itself is "killing" the people, however it appears to everyone else as random forms of accidents. Kindred basically has an internal timer on everyone's time to die, which is why they are always there at the right time.  And when it is "your time" you're basically given the choice of how you want to die. And then kindred "confirms" your death and applies your fate.  Kindreds arrow "is" the axe. Wolf "is" the army of people that chased after the kid and shot him multiple times with arrows and spears before finally stabbing him repeatedly. However the only people that see them are those already going to die.
God I hated those movies when I was younger.  Made me so freaking paranoid.

Tell me about it. One of my old jobs was cleaning up dead bodies + vehicle accidents off of the free way and I had semis flying by me at 90 mph :). I thought I was going to die about 100 times an hour.
So I'm confused about something. The guy who took Lamb's arrow was in the middle of a battle, but was the squire by himself or were the soldiers coming to him? Why would Kindred bother to chase him?

Yeah, that's what confused me about Kindred from the start. Do they actually kill a person or do they just influence how someone dies?
The lamb shot the soldier who got an axe to his heart for example. So what killed the squire who ran away? Did the wolf literally chew him up?

It looks like kindred merely makes whatever kills you truly fatal.
Without them you could take a hundreds stabs into your heart and you wouldn't die,you'll only die once they "kill" you.

However they do not choose when or how you die,that is up to you(and whatever kills you).

From what I can tell Kindred's only role is to sever the soul from the body at the moment of death. They don't deal the killing blow though. 

It was implied that the squire was chased by the enemy army into the woods, but how he died isn't clear. It could be anything from being cut down by a soldier's ax or simply tripping and breaking his neck on the fall. Either way Wolf got his chase.
The battle was coming to the squire. The squire ran instead of facing the enemy so Wolf chased after.
I like this style of writing. Shorter than the judgments, and not a full backstory, but I enjoy it.

I do wish we could have some more of the judgement-type old lore, but this is excellent. Developing the champions through scenes and stories seems to make much more vivid characters than simply telling who they are and what their history is.

Why do they hate the shadow island people except for Kalista?

Cause they be ghosts of death as well?

___
The denizens of the Shadow Isles aren't ghosts of death per say; they are undead entities which defy the natural occurrence of death at life's end.

The undead, being mostly specters, spirits, and ghouls, are abominations that linger somewhere between the boundaries of life and death; it's only natural that Kindred would spite those that do not embrace the concept of death and continue to exist beyond death in some twisted form or another.
___
Basically:

Life -> Death = Happy Kindred
Life -> Undeath = Extremely Unhappy Kindred

Karthus is an Undying Lich = Kindred Hates
Mordekaiser is Arguably the First Revenant = Kindred Hates
Hecarim is the Vanguard of Undeath = Kindred Hates
Yorick was a Human Gravedigger that died but continued to exist centuries after death as a Ghoul = Kindred Hates
Thresh was a Sadistic Jailer that was murdered but continued to exist after death as a Specter = Kindred Hates
___
I'm not so sure about Kalista, though.

Kalista doesn't hold any allegiance to the Shadow Isles, if I remember correctly, so Kindred might extend some leniency to Kalista.

Plus, Kalista aims to exact vengeance upon betrayers, scoundrels, traitors, deceivers, etc.
There isn't really a "I'll bring Undeath to Everyone in Runeterra" vibe coming from Kalista.
___
I should also point out Elise.

Elise is clearly affiliated with the Shadow Isles, but she doesn't seem to promote the agenda of undeath either.
She just lures people to Vilemaw; Vilemaw gobbles the people up and grants Elise some venom that extends her lifespan.

Vilemaw eats people -> People stay dead = Satisfied Kindred
Elise uses an elixir to extend her lifespan but really hasn't died yet = Satisfied Kindred

She keeps souls from passing on just like Thresh does, it's just that with Kalista they all sort of swarm together as a giant hive of revenge while Thresh keeps them imprisoned, but in both cases the souls are not going on to the afterlife.
Ya I suppose that is true but remember these people chose this fate. As it seems Kindred is ok with how you use your soul, only on how you want to die.

I find it a bit off as a story device if the champion can never be beaten (as far as we know). It seems like a similar problem with Bard, being too 'OP' in the role they play in Runeterra. If Kindred comes for everyone, what tension is there in their stories? How do they interact with other champions other than 'We are here to take you'? Other depictions of Death (such from Sandman and Discworld) have ways to interact with characters other than just showing up when they die. Death from Sandman has family and every hundred years takes the form of a mortal to remember how it is to be mortal. Death from Discworld is fascinated by mortals, has family, helpers and sidekicks and acted as Santa for a time, and can be beaten occasionally. Kindred to me just seems...uninteractive in interesting ways. Lamb is quick death, Wolf drawn out.

I don't understand why Kalista isn't an enemy to them. Yes, her reasons for what she does aren't like Thresh's but she still takes souls and keeps them from their final rest. To Kindred she should be no different than Thresh.
